verses.text: The people of Jerusalem made Ahaziah, the youngest son of Jehoram, king in his place, because the raiding party that came with the Arabs to the camp had killed all the older sons. So Ahaziah son of Jehoram became king of Judah.
verses.comment: The text underlines how the Lord preserves the Davidic line despite foreign threats, maintaining His covenant promises (see 2 Sam 7:12-16).

verses.text: Ahaziah was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem one year. His mother’s name was Athaliah, the granddaughter of Omri.
verses.comment: Some manuscripts, including the Septuagint and 2 Kings 8:26, list Ahaziah as twenty-two, while others have forty-two. The historical and genealogical context supports the age of twenty-two.

verses.text: He also followed the ways of the house of Ahab, for his mother influenced him to do what was evil.
verses.comment: The powerful role of Ahaziah’s mother shows the importance of spiritual formation in the home. The influence of the northern kingdom (house of Ahab) led Ahaziah away from fidelity to God’s covenant.

verses.text: He did what was evil in the sight of the Lord like the house of Ahab, for they were his advisors after the death of his father, to his destruction.
verses.comment: Evil leadership results in downfall, highlighting the need for spiritual discernment and obedience to God’s commands (Ps 1:1).

verses.text: He also followed their advice and went with Jehoram the son of Ahab king of Israel to make war against Hazael king of Aram at Ramoth-Gilead, and the Arameans wounded Joram.
verses.comment: Ahaziah’s alliance with the northern kingdom against God’s revealed will set him on a path toward divine judgment—reminiscent of other instances where improper alliances led to trouble (see 2 Sam 6:19).

verses.text: So Joram turned back to Jezreel to recover from the wounds which the Arameans had inflicted on him at Ramah, when he fought against Hazael king of Aram. Then Ahaziah the son of Jehoram, king of Judah, went down to Jezreel to visit Joram son of Ahab, because he was sick.
verses.comment: Ahaziah’s family connection with the northern kingdom continues to draw him into entanglement and destruction.

verses.text: But this was from God, that Ahaziah should be destroyed by going to Joram. For when he arrived, he went out with Joram against Jehu son of Nimshi, whom the Lord had anointed to destroy the house of Ahab.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty is highlighted; He works through human actions and alliances—even those made for evil—to bring about His judgment, illustrating the mystery of Providence.

verses.text: When Jehu was executing judgment on the house of Ahab, he found the officials of Judah and the sons of Ahaziah’s relatives, who were attending Ahaziah, and killed them.
verses.comment: Judgment falls not only on those who commit evil but also on those who enable or are complicit in wickedness. This foreshadows New Testament warnings against complicity in the sins of others (1 Tim 5:22).

verses.text: Ahaziah was found hiding in Samaria, so they brought him to Jehu, killed him, and buried him. They said, 'He is the grandson of Jehoshaphat, who sought the Lord with all his heart.' So the house of Ahaziah had no power to hold the kingdom.
verses.comment: Ahaziah’s death signifies the consequences of forsaking the covenant, but his burial out of respect for his grandfather points to God’s mercy and remembrance of the faithfulness of previous generations.

verses.text: Now when Athaliah, the mother of Ahaziah, saw that her son was dead, she arose and destroyed all the royal heirs of the house of Judah.
verses.comment: This massacre threatened the Davidic line, which was crucial for the fulfillment of God’s promises regarding the Messiah (Ps 132:11), highlighting providential protection of this lineage.

verses.text: But Jehosheba, the daughter of King Jehoram, took Joash son of Ahaziah, and secretly stole him away from among the king’s sons who were to be killed, and put him and his nurse in a bedroom. So Jehosheba, the wife of Jehoiada the priest (because she was Ahaziah’s sister), hid him from Athaliah so she could not kill him.
verses.comment: A faithful remnant preserved the royal lineage, underscoring how God works through individuals to fulfill His larger purposes. The role of Jehoiada the priest foreshadows how God uses ordained leaders to guard His people and the promise of the Messiah.

verses.text: He remained hidden with them in the house of God for six years, while Athaliah ruled over the land.
verses.comment: Joash’s preservation in the house of God prefigures the protection and formation of future leaders within the sanctuary. This waiting period is reminiscent of Christ’s own hidden life and the fulfillment of God’s plan in the fullness of time (Gal 4:4).
